item.title: Rise of the Ronin: How to Travel Between Regions
item.description:
Rise of the Ronin is an action RPG set in the Bakumatsu period in Japan. Players' decisions can change the story and shape history depending on who they help or leave behind. Ronins travel across Japan helping allies and fighting foes as powerful assassins.

If players focus on the main story, they will travel to two other regions, locking them out of the previous region's missions. However, nothing is set in stone, and traveling back in time to a different area is possible in Rise of the Ronin . Players can use this guide to learn how to travel between regions.

How to Travel Between Regions in Rise of the Ronin

The first region that players explore in Rise of the Ronin is Yokohama. Yokohama is made up of 20 areas, and there are plenty of side missions and interactions to complete. Chapter One of the main story also takes place in Yokohama, and players will be caught between two powerful parties.

Regardless of which side they're on, players go to the Edo Region during the chapter. They will lose access to unfinished missions and missed areas in Yokohama when they go to Edo. Luckily, players will get the opportunity to travel back to Yokohama and finish anything they need to.

After going to Edo, players will learn about the Testament of the Soul. The Testament of the Soul is a special book that gives players the power to return to other regions. Traveling between areas in Rise of the Ronin works slightly differently than most travel systems. Rather than simply going to another place, players will go back in time and can redo any missions or tie up loose ends.

The story can be changed as actions from the past affect the present. So, if players don't like the outcome of their decisions, they can do things differently the second time. Then they can return to the present and continue in the next region in two ways. Players can use the Testament of the Soul at their Longhouse in Yokohama.

Players can also open the System Menu and select "Return to your time" to go between regions.

Edo is added to the Testament of the Soul when players move on to Kyoto later in the main story. Redoing missions is a great way to earn XP and get new rewards. Players don't lose any of their stats when they go back in time and can take on more difficult missions.

The Testament of the Soul is divided into three sections: Ronin Missions, Bond Missions, and Areas. Players can complete all the different outcomes for each one, so they won't miss out on any trophies and rewards as they progress through Rise of the Ronin .

item.title: 10 Best Games Where You Fight With A Whip, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Whips are underrated weapons with unique gameplay opportunities and a satisfying crack sound.
  • Games like Darksiders 3, Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night, and Dead Cells feature whips as iconic weapons.
  • The history and legacy of the whip in games like Indiana Jones, Castlevania, and Elden Ring are influential and beloved.

Whips are usually the last thing that comes to mind when talking about weapons (ranking just above boomerangs). They rarely show up outside of some cough cough kink-ridden scenarios, but when they do, their presence can be surprisingly powerful.

Not only do whips offer unique gameplay opportunities by striking a balance between long-range and close-quarters combat, but there’s also no denying the intensely satisfying, sound-barrier-breaking crack they produce. Let’s not forget that whips were the weapon of choice for Indiana Jones, and a man with that much swagger surely knows the most stylish method of delivering a beating. Thankfully, these games got the memo and followed suit, allowing their players to wield whips to great effect.

10 Darksiders 3

Miracle Whip

For the third installment in the Darksiders series, Gunfire Games introduced fresh mechanics to shake up the formula. One standout addition was the whip. It was so iconic that it even earned a place on the game’s cover.

Wielded by Fury, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, the whip became her signature weapon as she set out to vanquish the physical embodiments of the Seven Deadly Sins. However, players weren’t limited to just the whip in Darksiders 3 —Fury’s arsenal also included swords, flails, daggers, and a touch of magic, but the whip was definitely the highlight.

9 La-Mulana

The Indie Version Of Indy

Indiana Jones is like the J.R.R. Tolkien of whips. If developers include a whip in their game, they have to reference him or go out of their way to set themselves apart. Or they can just do what GR3 Project did with La-Mulana and make a loving bootleg version of Indy without any attempts to change a thing. Well, except for the name.

Despite all this, La-Mulana is a whip-cracking good time, offering challenging platforming and a heartfelt tribute to classic MSX games. It was even beloved enough to warrant both a sequel and a full-blown remake.

8 Bloodstained: Ritual Of The Night

2.5D-Style Whipping

Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night is an unabashed spiritual successor to Castlevania, and if a game is following in the footsteps of such a legendary franchise, it had better bring a whip. Otherwise, what’s the point?

Indie studio ArtPlay understood this perfectly. Their 2019 Metroidvania-inspired hit lets players wield whips—along with an arsenal of other weapons—to battle monsters and demons. Set in 18th-century England during the Industrial Revolution, the game tasks players with stopping a dark force before it makes the country even more dark and miserable (sorry, England).

7 Bloodborne

Part Walking Stick, Part Serrated Whip

Wait, there’s a whip in Bloodborne ? Yes, but chances are, many players never gave it a second glance. That’s because it’s disguised as the very dapper “Threaded Cane,” the weakest of the game’s three starting weapons. For a game as brutally difficult as Bloodborne , who can blame players for choosing the path of least resistance?

However, beginner players shouldn’t shrug this choice off. With its incredible reach, ability to hit multiple enemies, and sheer speed, the Threaded Cane is a solid choice for anyone taking on the eldritch horrors of Yharnam.

6 Vampire Survivors

Antonio Belpaese’s Weapon Of Choice

Combine an addictive roguelike with a dopamine-fueled shoot ‘em up, and the result is the sleeper hit Vampire Survivors . For players just picking up this game, the first weapon they’ll be dealt is none other than a whip.

It’s a solid starting choice, simple to use, with decent reach and respectable damage. However, as the horde grows and the chaos ramps up, players may want to swap it out for something a bit more devastating, such as magical projectiles or rapid-fire weapons.

5 Dead Cells

Whipping Up A Solid Roguelike Metroidvania

It seems Metroidvania games have a soft spot for whips, and honestly, it makes perfect sense. One of the finest examples of this trend is Dead Cells , a roguelike masterpiece that blends fluid gameplay, ever-changing levels, and the dreaded yet exhilarating permadeath mechanic.

When it comes to whips, Dead Cells offers plenty of choices. The most iconic is Valmont’s Whip, a name that sounds suspiciously close to Castlevania’s Belmont heroes. However, the real standout is the Whip Sword, which masterfully combines the bonking power of a sword with the long-range finesse of a whip.

4 Spelunky

Climbing Ropes And Whipping Tropes

The godfather of roguelites and one of the best platformers of all time, Spelunky is yet another title on this list that wears its influences on its bomber jacket sleeve. Except this time, Indy is spelunking sideways through procedurally generated tunnels.

The whip in Spelunky isn’t just for show; it’s an essential tool for fending off enemies, deflecting objects, and cracking open treasures. With a trusty whip in hand, rescuing damsels and exploring the unknown becomes child’s play. Scratch that; it's probably not a good idea to give children whips.

3 Indiana Jones And The Great Circle

Multi-Purpose Tool

When Bethesda first unveiled its Indiana Jones game, some fans were skeptical about its first-person perspective. Fortunately, those concerns were quickly put to rest. What fans got with Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is, without a doubt, one of the best Indiana Jones games in the franchise’s 40+ year history.

Of course, no Indiana Jones adventure would be complete without his signature whip, but in this case, Indy's signature weapon isn’t just for cracking at Nazis. It’s a multi-purpose tool for swinging through levels like Spider-Man and solving intricate puzzles. Think of it as a Swiss Army whip.

2 Elden Ring

Now Watch Me Whip

Elden Ring is overflowing with weapons. We could count them (and someone definitely has), but take our word for it: there’s a lot. So, naturally, with that many options to choose from, the game was bound to include a solid selection of whips.

Whether crafted from candlesticks, braids of giant's hair, or even teeth, FromSoftware put serious thought into these unique weapons. They’re particularly suited for Dexterity-focused builds, but for those craving a truly chaotic playthrough, dual-wielding whips is an absolute blast and is wholeheartedly recommended. As a bonus fact, all three Dark Souls games let players use whips, but they don't have the same "oomph."

1 Castlevania: Symphony Of The Night

A Whip Lovingly Handed Down From Generation To Generation

The Belmont clan sure loves a good whip. In fact, their weapon of choice, the legendary “Vampire Killer,” has been a vampire-slaying staple for generations. Add a Morning Star to the mix, and the result is the quintessential Castlevania tool. So when Simon Belmont joined the Super Smash Bros. roster, it was only fitting that he brought his iconic whip along for the fight.

If there’s one Castlevania game that truly honors the whip’s legacy, it’s Castlevania: Symphony of the Night . Even though this classic shifted away from a whip-wielding protagonist, the “Vampire Killer” still makes a well-earned appearance in one of the greatest action RPGs of all time.

item.title: 8 Strongest Pokemon With Multiple Forms
item.description:
Summary

  • Zacian and Zamazenta can transform into their Crowned Sword and Crowned Shield forms, gaining Steel-type and two powerful signature moves.
  • Hoopa can change into Unbound form, gaining the type combination of Psychic and Dark, increased stats, and an impressive signature move called Hyperspace Fury.
  • Primal Groudon and Kyogre undergo Primal Reversion in Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire , which allows them to become extremely powerful.

The Pokemon franchise is filled to the brim with fresh and exciting mechanics that give its titular creatures access to brand-new forms, like Mega Evolution, Regional Variants, or Gigantamax. But what about the old-school method? What about all the Pokemon that can change forms regardless of a specific gimmick?

That’s right, several distinct Pokemon can change into a different form for in-game lore reasons, and most of the time, these transformations give them a significant boost in battles. The following Pokemon are the strongest examples of this in the entire franchise, but it’s important to keep in mind that the aforementioned mechanics (Mega Evolutions, Regional Variants, and Gigantamax Forms) will not be accounted for in this list, as the alternate forms need to be innate to each Pokemon’s unique biology.

8 Zacian And Zamazenta

Heroes Of Many Battles / Crowned Sword And Crowned Shield

  • Base Stat Total: 670 (Crowned)

The Box Art Legendaries of Pokemon Sword and Shield , Zacian and Zamazenta , are particularly interesting because they are not at full power when the player first encounters them at the beginning of the adventure. These base forms are called “Hero of Many Battles,” and to wield their incredible weapons and reach their fullest potential, they both need to be equipped with the Rusted Sword and Rusted Shield, respectively.

Zacian is a pure Fairy-type and Zamazenta is a pure Fighting-type, but when they transform into their Crowned Sword and Crowned Shield forms, they gain the secondary Steel-type. On top of that, these forms have better stats and give them access to their destructive signature moves: Behemoth Blade and Behemoth Bash. These moves are extremely strong, especially when used against a Dynamax or Gigantamax Pokemon, like Eternamax Eternatus.

7 Hoopa

Confined / Unbound

  • Base Stat Total: 680 (Unbound)

Like most Mythical Pokemon before it, Hoopa is stronger than the majority of regular Pokemon, but it's way less strong than other creatures with similar base stats, especially because it’s notably brought down by its horrendous type combination of Psychic and Ghost. However, everything changes when it interacts with a Prison Bottle, which allows the Mischief Pokemon to transform into its Unbound form.

Hoopa Unbound is a force to be reckoned with. Not only do its stats gain 80 more points in total, but it also changes its typing to Psychic and Dark, which overall have fewer weaknesses. Lastly, it gets access to Hyperspace Fury, a Dark-type physical move that does 100 points of damage, can break through Protect, and ignores the target’s Defense stat. The fact that such a cute and small Pokemon can turn into such a massive beast of destruction is almost impossible to believe.

6 Dialga, Palkia, And Giratina

Altered / Origin

  • Base Stat Total: 680 (Origin Formes)

Giratina is famous for being one of the very first Box Art Legendaries to ever get an alternate form. Pokemon Platinum introduced its Origin Forme, slightly improving its stats and changing its ability to Levitate. This sole feature made Giratina significantly more interesting and stronger than the other two Pokemon of Myth, Dialga and Palkia .

As a result, Pokemon Legends: Arceus introduced brand-new Origin Formes for the other two Pokemon to level the playing field. While Origin Dialga and Origin Palkia don’t get new abilities, they also have better stats, not to mention that their signature moves (Roar of Time and Spacial Rend, respectively) also receive a remarkable boost when they are in these forms. Furthermore, Giratina’s signature move, Shadow Force, also received the same buff in this game.

5 Calyrex

Normal / Shadow Rider / Ice Rider

  • Base Stat Total: 680 (Riders)

At first glance, the Legendary Pokemon Calyrex doesn’t seem particularly strong or intimidating, as it has a bizarre design, a disadvantageous type combination, and a base stat total of just 500, which is quite mediocre for a Legendary. But, of course, when it uses the Reins of Unity on one of its two steeds—Spectrier and Glastrier—Calyrex can turn into its potent Shadow Rider and Ice Rider forms.

A base stat total of 680 is already a noteworthy improvement, but these two forms stand out in the competitive Pokemon scene because of their solid type combinations, their two powerful signature moves (Astral Barrage and Glacial Lance) and, most important of all, their signature ability, As One, which basically lets them use two abilities at the same time. Needless to say, Calyrex would be nothing without Spectrier and Glastrier, and vice versa.

4 Kyurem

Normal / Black / White

  • Base Stat Total : 700 (Black/White)

Kyurem is notorious for having the unexpected ability to fuse with the other two members of the Tao Trio, Zekrom and Reshiram, by using an item known as DNA Splicers. That’s how it gets access to its Black and White forms, and is just one step away from turning into the original dragon that was split into three different Pokemon.

Naturally, Black and White Kyurem get a small but important boost to their base stats and access to Zekrom and Reshiram’s signature abilities (which can ignore other Pokemon’s abilities) and their devastating signature moves. On top of that, these two forms of Kyurem can learn Freeze Shock and Ice Burn, respectively, two devastating Ice-type attacks with the destructive effects of the Electric and Fire-types.

3 Zygarde

10% / 50% / Complete

  • Base Stat Total: 708 (Complete)

When it was introduced back in Pokemon X and Y , Zygarde was a seemingly normal Legendary Pokemon with a serpentine appearance hiding deep within an innocuous cave. However, in Pokemon Sun and Moon , fans were shocked to find that the Order Pokemon actually has five different forms (depending on how many Zygarde Cells it holds), of which only three are available to use in-game.

The wolf-like 10% form is relatively weak, but its Complete Forme stands out for being one of the most powerful Pokemon in the entire franchise. With a solid type combination of Dragon and Ground and four different signature moves, including the devastating Core Enforcer, Complete Zygarde is a true force to be reckoned with, and all of its forms will hopefully play an important role in the upcoming Pokemon Legends: Z-A .

2 Necrozma

Normal / Dusk Mane / Dawn Wings / Ultra

  • Base Stat Total : 754 (Ultra)

Necrozma took what made Kyurem interesting and elevated it to a whole new level. The Prism Pokemon can also fuse with the two Box Art Legendaries of its generation, Solgaleo and Lunala, to gain access to its Dusk Mane and Dawn Wings forms. These two variations of Necrozma not only obtain the secondary type and the signature moves of their respective Pokemon, but they also receive 80 more points to their stats.

Dusk Mane and Dawn Wings Necrozma are already quite impressive on their own, but unlike Kyurem, Necrozma also has access to an incredibly powerful third form when it holds the Ultranecrozium Z, called Ultra Necrozma. This is a Psychic and Dragon Pokemon (which is an excellent combination of types) with an impressive base stat total of 754 and an overpowered signature ability named Neuroforce that powers up all of its super-effective attacks. On top of that, it has exclusive access to Light That Burns the Sky, which is the most powerful Z-Move in the game. There’s no denying that Ultra Necrozma is one of the most imposing, threatening, and destructive creatures in the franchise, and it’s a good thing that it's not available in every single Pokemon game.

1 Groudon And Kyogre

Primal Reversion

  • Base Stat Total: 770 (Primal)

When compared to other Box Art Legendaries introduced after them, Groudon and Kyogre used to seem a lot less strong and important. Fortunately, the 3DS remakes of the generation three games, Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire , gave them a much-needed upgrade called Primal Reversion, which inadvertently turned them into two of the most powerful Pokemon in the entire franchise.

Primal Groudon and Primal Kyogre gain 100 whole points to their stats, receive two devastating signature moves (Precipice Blades and Origin Pulse), and gain enhanced versions of their weather-summoning abilities that can cancel each other out. This is especially important for Primal Groudon, which has the type combination of Ground and Fire, so now it can fight its rival on equal footing. Needless to say, Primal Groudon and Primal Kyogre are extremely destructive because they’re designed to be stopped by Mega Rayquaza, which, in turn, is possibly the most overpowered Pokemon ever created.
